definition:
If $G$ is a group and $X$ a set, then $X$ is called a left $G$-Set if
there exists a mapping $\lambda : G \times X \rightarrow X$ with

$$\lambda(g_1,\lambda(g_2,x)) = \lambda(g_1 g_2, x)$$

or shorter with $\lambda(g,x) = gx$

$$g_1(g_2(x)) = (g_1 g_2)(x)$$

for all $x \in X$ and $g_1,g_2 \in G$. And when $G$ acts on a set $X$,
the set $X$ is always a $G$-set.\
\
$X$ is called a right $G$-Set if there exists a mapping
$\lambda : X \times G \rightarrow X$ with

$$\lambda(\lambda(x,g_2),g_1) = \lambda(x,g_2 g_1)$$
